SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES - A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A. A brief explanation to the purpose

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who has lived in this province will have experienced exactly the same circumstances as another. Some of the questions here will apply only to persons who have lived in the province for more than ten years; others may be applicable to persons who have lived in the province for less than ten years.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who have lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Life: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Have?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered it, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here (X) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer:

- All Questionnaires
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Presentation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent records of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

University of Saskatchewan
Saskatoon, Sask.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Our friends and relatives didn't think much of the idea of coming west on account of the Indian massacres they had heard about (whether or not we came).

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other group)?

My uncle had already established himself in the west so I came back east and bought a seat on the same railroad to Maine, Mont., which only contained some half a dozen buildings including a two story hotel and has grown into a very nice city.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

We had a very nice journey west on the train taking our generous farmer with us. He didn't say anything about the way—just one incident I will have to mention is the fact that we had been seen by a man who said "there goes a nigger" who gave me a rather harsh look at such a satirical remark.

14. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

My Uncle and Brother had come to Saskatchewan a frame house where we had a home to come to when we settled on Battle creek about twenty miles from Kansas.

15. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

We have always lived within four miles where I am at present situated which has been a very pleasant home since I was married which has been over forty years.

16. How long have you lived before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

On our New England farm my father made a good living raising the numerous which soon consisted of milking cows and selling butter, raising fruit, wood, a good apple orchard and tobacco raising. But since we came west it has been stock raising mainly there wasn't any raised farming till the farmers settled.

18. Was this your first coming to Western Canada? How did you travel?

On our New England farm my father made a good living considering the resources which consisted of milking cows and selling butter, raising hogs, a good apple orchard and tobacco raising. It since we came west it has been stock raising mainly there wasn't any raised farming till the farmers settle.
My husband's name is Robert Stirling and we moved into a house in Battle Creek, Montana. We came through the Canadian government agencies and many of them are still living on the same farms as when we left.

When we came to Montana we took what was called "settling rights" for the land we wanted in this southern part of Idaho. We were quite a happy lot and could put up all the hay we needed within five miles of home but still had to practice plenty of economy in this undeveloped country. The stores were mostly towards a living though everything was cheap.

We would put new fat on our steers and another pair later.

Old habits die hard, we could make do another pair later.

We didn't travel about very much in the early years. For business, a travelling church, visiting relatives, etc., how often? How far? By what means of travel?

We would ride on a saddle horse for the mail once a week which was twenty miles to Battle Creek.

The post office and brought by stage from Maple Creek.

The world took a team and wagon and during our prosperity from Maple Creek once or twice a year which was a distance of thirty miles. We lived about twenty miles from church, stores and Jurnell with a saddle horse along the way. We didn't want much of anyone's help in which riding the old.
The whole family was an average of once a week at first until the homesteaders were away attending to all the ranchers that settled on Battle Creek were Canadian citizens buying the land that they lived about eight miles down the creek until the same we came through the advice of government agencies.

Our family were the only ones that came out and many of them are still living on the same farms as when we left.

When we came to Canada we took what was called "squatter's rights" in the land warrant issued in the southern part of Saskatchewan. We were granted a happy lot we could put up all the house needed within five miles of some but still had to practice plenty of pioneering in this undeveloped country. The trees were mostly towards a living though everything was cheap.

We would put new feet in our old things after four or five old shoes in case we could make another pair later.

We didn't travel about very much in the early years. We would ride on a saddle horse for the mail once a week which was twenty miles to Battle Creek post office and bought by stage from Maple Creek. We would take a team and wagon and bring our groceries from Maple Creek once or twice a year which was a distance of fifty miles. We lived about twenty-five miles from church services and surrounded with a saddle horse along with other folks along the way. We didn't want much of anything else in which making you feel.

35. When did you make up your mind to try it out? When did you make this decision?

We came to Sashakwehun to make a permanent home there was everything nice with a little labor that anyone should want. There were no taxes when we came for the land wasn't assessed and free range in abundance. There were no farms and the girls my age did mostly the milking.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

There were no people moved away from the district before 1914, that was about the time the farmers started to settle the vacant land.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

When the depression came there was a general uneasiness in the district with dry years and low prices most of the farmers moved away but a few are left that could obtain more land for mining.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My husband's Uncle Mr. Isaac Stirling was elected a Member in the Provincial Government at Regina and served one term it would be about in the early 20's. I was a secretary of our School District for ten years and my brother was Secretary of adjoining district a few years earlier.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

My brother Earl Nash owned the first car in the district which was a Model T touring car. He also started the first post office in the community which he called Nashlyn about 1912. There wasn't much social activity other than country dances.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). The railway company has built a branch line from Bonny which passes our place within a mile of where we live and has named a side station after the Nashlyn post office. This is all rolling prairie around us and there isn't many prominent works of nature and their names still remain as original. There is a hill about fifteen miles east of us called Old Man on this Back which was an Indian name given many years ago before we came here. The creeks have retained their original names.
There were no people moved away from the district before 1914, that was about the time the farmers started to settle the vacant land.

When the depression came there was a general uncertainty in the district with dry years and low prices most of the farmers more or less had a fall off that year that would be hard to forget.

My husband Uncle Mr. S. said Stirling was elected a member in the Provincial Government at Regina and served one term it would be about in the early 20's. I was a secretary of our school district for some years and my brothers were deputy for another.

My father Earl Nash owned the first car in the district which was a Model T touring car. He also started the first post office in the community which he called Nashby in about 1915. There wasn't much social activity other than country dances.

The railway company has built a branch line from Nashby which passes our place within a mile of where we live and has named a siding station after the Nashby post office. This is all rolling prairie around us and there isn't many prominent marks of nature and their names still remain as original. There is a hill about fifteen miles east called Old Man on this road which was an old Indian camp many years ago before we came here. The settlers have named their original names.
We are just about the last of the pioneers in our district though others have married might be able to supply some of them. I have no records or diary but these names of those mentioned might be after 1875 and some photographs that might be left.

What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came here?

I think the greatest improvement in my community are the means of transportation from the horse and buggy days and also the mechanized farming.

The early settlers had so many years of manual labor. The means of entertainment are more modern like we have a picture show every Saturday night in the hall at Larned which enthralls the old as well as the young.

I have four children two girls and two boys; the oldest girl is married and runs a hotel in Greenock; she taught school for ten years, the next girl took a commercial course and works for an accountant in Lethbridge; her name is Yelma Stirling; the oldest boy Raymond Stirling is farming at home and Stewart Stirling owns a garage at Athabasca.

What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

I think the greatest improvement in our community are the means of transportation from the horse and buggy days and also the mechanized farming; the early settlers had so many years of manual labor.
